page.title: Human rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 24: Line 24:
Graffiti artist Ganzeer, film director Aida El-Kashef, and musician/painter Nadim Amin AKA NadimX were arrested<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/5/35/13024/Arts--Culture/Stage--Street/CIC-condemns-arrest-of-artists-by-military-.aspx |title=CIC condemns arrest of artists by military - Stage & Street - Arts & Culture - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> for posting a poster<ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitpic.com/52p7n6 |title=#FreeGanzeer - Hi Res Poster That Ganzeer Got Arrested for. on Twitpic |publisher=Twitpic.com |date=2011-05-26 |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> that offended the military police. They were released later that day.<ref>{{cite web|author=New York Times, USA |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/27/egypt-gearing-up-for-a-second-revolutionary-round/ |title=Egypt: Gearing Up for a Second Revolutionary Round Â· Global Voices |publisher=Globalvoicesonline.org |date=27 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> "I donât know why we were transferred to the military prosecution" said graffiti artist Mohamed Fahmy, a 29-year-old Egyptian artist,<ref>{{cite web|author=Jack Shenker in Cairo |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/may/19/egypts-uprising-diy-art-cairo-streets |title=Egypt's uprising brings DIY spirit out on to the streets | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> who goes by Ganzeer on Twitter, minutes after his release. He said that in custody he and others talked about "politics and democracy".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/graffiti-artist-says-online-outcry-may-have-sped-up-release.html |title=Graffiti artist says online outcry may have sped up release |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/05/26/egypts-youth-vocal-against-army |title=Egypt's youth vocal against army | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref>
Graffiti artist Ganzeer, film director Aida El-Kashef, and musician/painter Nadim Amin AKA NadimX were arrested<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/5/35/13024/Arts--Culture/Stage--Street/CIC-condemns-arrest-of-artists-by-military-.aspx |title=CIC condemns arrest of artists by military - Stage & Street - Arts & Culture - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> for posting a poster<ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitpic.com/52p7n6 |title=#FreeGanzeer - Hi Res Poster That Ganzeer Got Arrested for. on Twitpic |publisher=Twitpic.com |date=2011-05-26 |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> that offended the military police. They were released later that day.<ref>{{cite web|author=New York Times, USA |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/27/egypt-gearing-up-for-a-second-revolutionary-round/ |title=Egypt: Gearing Up for a Second Revolutionary Round Â· Global Voices |publisher=Globalvoicesonline.org |date=27 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> "I donât know why we were transferred to the military prosecution" said graffiti artist Mohamed Fahmy, a 29-year-old Egyptian artist,<ref>{{cite web|author=Jack Shenker in Cairo |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/may/19/egypts-uprising-diy-art-cairo-streets |title=Egypt's uprising brings DIY spirit out on to the streets | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> who goes by Ganzeer on Twitter, minutes after his release. He said that in custody he and others talked about "politics and democracy".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/graffiti-artist-says-online-outcry-may-have-sped-up-release.html |title=Graffiti artist says online outcry may have sped up release |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/05/26/egypts-youth-vocal-against-army |title=Egypt's youth vocal against army | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref>
â
Another activist who was detained after Mubarak's ousting was Maikel Nabil Sanad,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maikelnabil.com/2010/12/my-cv.html |title=About me |publisher=http://www.maikelnabil.com/ |date=5 December 2010 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> a political activist and blogger. In April 2009 he founded the No to Compulsory Military Service movement. He declared his conscientious objection, demanding to be exempted from military service. Instead, he was arrested on 12 November 2010 by military police but was released two days later, and finally exempted from service on medical grounds. Sanad participated actively in the Egyptian revolution, highlighting the fact that Egypt has effectively been ruled by the military for six decades. He was arrested on 4 February by military police and tortured, but released 27 hours later. He was arrested in his home in the Ain Shams neighbourhood in Cairo at about 10 PM on 28 March 2011 by military police. He was only able to call his brother the next day to inform him of his arrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wri-irg.org/node/12513 |title=Egyptian Pacifist Maikel Nabil Sanad Arrested for Insulting Military |publisher=http://www.wri-irg.org/ |date=30 March 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> Sanad was sentenced to three years' imprisonment on charges of "insulting the military" in his post "The Army and The People Were Never One Hand" on maikelnabil.com<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maikelnabil.com/2011/03/army-and-people-wasnt-ever-one-hand.html |title=The Army and The People Wasn't Ever One Hand |publisher=http://www.maikelnabil.com/ |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> by the 10th of Ramadan military court in Nasr City near Cairo on 10 April. Before this, he was imprisoned in a special punishment cell at El Marg prison, which did not allow him any sunlight. In addition, his cell mates threatened him. Sanad demanded a doctor, as he suffers from unstable blood pressure and needs regular medication and medical attention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wri-irg.org/node/13004 |title=Imprisoned Pacifist Blogger Maikel Nabil Sanad in Solitary Confinement |publisher=http://www.wri-irg.org/ |date=23 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref>
+
Another activist who was detained after Mubarak's ousting was Maikel Nabil Sanad,<ref>http://www.maikelnabil.com/2010/12/my-cv.html</ref> a political activist and blogger. In April 2009 he founded the No to Compulsory Military Service movement. He declared his conscientious objection, demanding to be exempted from military service. Instead, he was arrested on 12 November 2010 by military police but was released two days later, and finally exempted from service on medical grounds. Sanad participated actively in the Egyptian revolution, highlighting the fact that Egypt has effectively been ruled by the military for six decades. He was arrested on 4 February by military police and tortured, but released 27 hours later. He was arrested in his home in the Ain Shams neighbourhood in Cairo at about 10 PM on 28 March 2011 by military police. He was only able to call his brother the next day to inform him of his arrest.<ref>http://www.wri-irg.org/node/12513</ref> Sanad was sentenced to three years' imprisonment on charges of "insulting the military" in his post "The Army and The People Were Never One Hand" on maikelnabil.com<ref>http://www.maikelnabil.com/2011/03/army-and-people-wasnt-ever-one-hand.html</ref> by the 10th of Ramadan military court in Nasr City near Cairo on 10 April. Before this, he was imprisoned in a special punishment cell at El Marg prison, which did not allow him any sunlight. In addition, his cell mates threatened him. Sanad demanded a doctor, as he suffers from unstable blood pressure and needs regular medication and medical attention.<ref>http://www.wri-irg.org/node/13004</ref>
Egyptian blogger and activist [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]], television host [[Reem Maged]] and journalist [[Nabil Sharaf El-Din]] were given a summons on 30 May 2011 to appear before military prosecution after Maged brought Hamalawy on her show where he criticized the role of the military police, holding the head of the military police responsible for torturing activists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/13270/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-journalists-to-be-questioned-tomorrow-by-.aspx |title=Egyptian journalists to be questioned tomorrow by military for denouncing the torture of activists - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref> They were released Tuesday after "chatting" with Military Prosecution and Hossam el-Hamalawy was asked to hand in reports of army abuses to authorities.<ref name="DailyEgypt">{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/blogger-asked-to-hand-reports-of-army-abuses-to-authorities.html |title=Blogger asked to hand reports of army abuses to authorities |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref>
Egyptian blogger and activist [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]], television host [[Reem Maged]] and journalist [[Nabil Sharaf El-Din]] were given a summons on 30 May 2011 to appear before military prosecution after Maged brought Hamalawy on her show where he criticized the role of the military police, holding the head of the military police responsible for torturing activists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/13270/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-journalists-to-be-questioned-tomorrow-by-.aspx |title=Egyptian journalists to be questioned tomorrow by military for denouncing the torture of activists - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref> They were released Tuesday after "chatting" with Military Prosecution and Hossam el-Hamalawy was asked to hand in reports of army abuses to authorities.<ref name="DailyEgypt">{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/blogger-asked-to-hand-reports-of-army-abuses-to-authorities.html |title=Blogger asked to hand reports of army abuses to authorities |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref>
